trans-unit.source: Deploying the Azure Rights Management Connector
trans-unit.target: Deploying the Azure Rights Management Connector

trans-unit.source: Use this information to learn about the Microsoft Rights Management (RMS) connector and how you can use it to provide information protection with existing on-premises deployments that use Microsoft Exchange Server, Microsoft SharePoint Server, or file servers that run Windows Server and use the File Classification Infrastructure (FCI) capability of File Server Resource Manager.
trans-unit.target: Use this information to learn about the Microsoft Rights Management (RMS) connector and how you can use it to provide information protection with existing on-premises deployments that use Microsoft Exchange Server, Microsoft SharePoint Server, or file servers that run Windows Server and use the File Classification Infrastructure (FCI) capability of File Server Resource Manager.

trans-unit.source: For a high-level example scenario with screenshots, see the <link><linkText>Automatically protecting files on file servers running Windows Server and File Classification Infrastructure</linkText><title></title></link> section in the <link><linkText>What is Azure Rights Management?</linkText><title></title></link> topic.
trans-unit.target: For a high-level example scenario with screenshots, see the <link><linkText>Automatically protecting files on file servers running Windows Server and File Classification Infrastructure</linkText><title></title></link> section in the <link><linkText>What is Azure Rights Management?</linkText><title></title></link> topic.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Overview of the Microsoft Rights Management connector
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Overview of the Microsoft Rights Management connector

trans-unit.source: The Microsoft Rights Management (RMS) connector lets you quickly enable existing on-premises servers to use their Information Rights Management (IRM) functionality with the cloud-based Microsoft Rights Management service (Azure RMS).
trans-unit.target: The Microsoft Rights Management (RMS) connector lets you quickly enable existing on-premises servers to use their Information Rights Management (IRM) functionality with the cloud-based Microsoft Rights Management service (Azure RMS).

trans-unit.source: With this functionality, IT and users can easily protect documents and pictures both inside your organization and outside, without having to install additional infrastructure or establish trust relationships with other organizations.
trans-unit.target: With this functionality, IT and users can easily protect documents and pictures both inside your organization and outside, without having to install additional infrastructure or establish trust relationships with other organizations.

trans-unit.source: You can use this connector even if some of your users are connecting to online services, in a hybrid scenario.
trans-unit.target: You can use this connector even if some of your users are connecting to online services, in a hybrid scenario.

trans-unit.source: For example, some users' mailboxes use Exchange Online and some users' mailboxes use Exchange Server.
trans-unit.target: For example, some users' mailboxes use Exchange Online and some users' mailboxes use Exchange Server.

trans-unit.source: After you install the RMS connector, all users can protect and consume emails and attachments by using Azure RMS, and information protection works seamlessly between the two deployment configurations.
trans-unit.target: After you install the RMS connector, all users can protect and consume emails and attachments by using Azure RMS, and information protection works seamlessly between the two deployment configurations.

trans-unit.source: The RMS connector is a small-footprint service that you install on-premises, on servers that run Windows Server 2012 R2, Windows Server 2012, or Windows Server 2008 R2.
trans-unit.target: The RMS connector is a small-footprint service that you install on-premises, on servers that run Windows Server 2012 R2, Windows Server 2012, or Windows Server 2008 R2.

trans-unit.source: In addition to running the connector on physical computers, you can also run it on virtual machines, including Azure IaaS VMs.
trans-unit.target: In addition to running the connector on physical computers, you can also run it on virtual machines, including Azure IaaS VMs.

trans-unit.source: After you install and configure the connector, it acts as a communications interface (a relay) between the on-premises servers and the cloud service.
trans-unit.target: After you install and configure the connector, it acts as a communications interface (a relay) between the on-premises servers and the cloud service.

trans-unit.source: If you manage your own tenant key for Azure RMS (the bring you own key, or BYOK scenario), the RMS connector and the on-premises servers that use it do not access the hardware security module (HSM) that contains your tenant key.
trans-unit.target: If you manage your own tenant key for Azure RMS (the bring you own key, or BYOK scenario), the RMS connector and the on-premises servers that use it do not access the hardware security module (HSM) that contains your tenant key.

trans-unit.source: This is because all cryptographic operations that use the tenant key are performed in Azure RMS, and not on-premises.
trans-unit.target: This is because all cryptographic operations that use the tenant key are performed in Azure RMS, and not on-premises.

trans-unit.source: The RMS connector supports the following on-premises servers: Exchange Server, SharePoint Server, and file servers that run Windows Server and use File Classification Infrastructure to classify and apply policies to Office documents in a folder.
trans-unit.target: The RMS connector supports the following on-premises servers: Exchange Server, SharePoint Server, and file servers that run Windows Server and use File Classification Infrastructure to classify and apply policies to Office documents in a folder.

trans-unit.source: If you want to protect all files types using File Classification, do not use the RMS connector, but instead, use the <link><linkText>RMS Protection cmdlets</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: If you want to protect all files types using File Classification, do not use the RMS connector, but instead, use the <link><linkText>RMS Protection cmdlets</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: For supported versions of these on-premises servers, see “On-premises servers that support Azure RMS” in the <link><linkText>Applications that support Azure RMS</linkText><title></title></link> section of the <link><linkText>Requirements for Azure Rights Management</linkText><title></title></link> topic.
trans-unit.target: For supported versions of these on-premises servers, see “On-premises servers that support Azure RMS” in the <link><linkText>Applications that support Azure RMS</linkText><title></title></link> section of the <link><linkText>Requirements for Azure Rights Management</linkText><title></title></link> topic.

trans-unit.source: Use the following sections to help you plan for, install, and configure the RMS connector.
trans-unit.target: Use the following sections to help you plan for, install, and configure the RMS connector.

trans-unit.source: You must then do some post installation configuration so that your servers can use the connector.
trans-unit.target: You must then do some post installation configuration so that your servers can use the connector.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Prerequisites for the RMS connector
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Prerequisites for the RMS connector

trans-unit.source: Before you install the RMS connector, make sure that the following requirements are in place.
trans-unit.target: Before you install the RMS connector, make sure that the following requirements are in place.

trans-unit.source: Requirement
trans-unit.target: Requirement

trans-unit.source: More information
trans-unit.target: More information

trans-unit.source: The Rights Management (RMS) service is activated
trans-unit.target: The Rights Management (RMS) service is activated

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Activating Azure Rights Management</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Activating Azure Rights Management</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: Directory synchronization between your on-premises Active Directory forests and Azure Active Directory
trans-unit.target: Directory synchronization between your on-premises Active Directory forests and Azure Active Directory

trans-unit.source: After RMS is activated, Azure Active Directory must be configured to work with the users and groups in your Active Directory database.Important: You must do this directory synchronization step for the RMS connector to work, even for a test network.
trans-unit.target: After RMS is activated, Azure Active Directory must be configured to work with the users and groups in your Active Directory database.Important: You must do this directory synchronization step for the RMS connector to work, even for a test network.

trans-unit.source: Although you can use Office 365 and Azure Active Directory by using accounts that you manually create in Azure Active Directory, this connector requires that the accounts in Azure Active Directory are synchronized with Active Directory Domain Services; manual password synchronization is not sufficient.<html></html><html></html>For more information, see the following resources:<html></html><html></html><link><linkText>Instructions for configuring your Azure AD tenant</linkText><title></title></link><html></html><html></html><link><linkText>Instructions for enabling directory synchronization with AAD using DirSync</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: Although you can use Office 365 and Azure Active Directory by using accounts that you manually create in Azure Active Directory, this connector requires that the accounts in Azure Active Directory are synchronized with Active Directory Domain Services; manual password synchronization is not sufficient.<html></html><html></html>For more information, see the following resources:<html></html><html></html><link><linkText>Instructions for configuring your Azure AD tenant</linkText><title></title></link><html></html><html></html><link><linkText>Instructions for enabling directory synchronization with AAD using DirSync</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: Optional but recommended:<html></html><html></html>Enable federation between your on-premises Active Directory and Azure Active Directory
trans-unit.target: Optional but recommended:<html></html><html></html>Enable federation between your on-premises Active Directory and Azure Active Directory

trans-unit.source: You can enable identity federation between your on-premises directory and Azure Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: You can enable identity federation between your on-premises directory and Azure Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: This configuration enables a more seamless user experience by using single sign-on to the RMS service.
trans-unit.target: This configuration enables a more seamless user experience by using single sign-on to the RMS service.

trans-unit.source: Without single sign on, users are prompted for their credentials before they can use rights-protected content.<html></html><html></html>For instructions to configure federation by using Active Directory Federation Services (AD FS) between Active Directory Domain Services and Azure Active Directory, see the <link><linkText>Checklist: Use AD FS to implement and manage single sign-on</linkText><title></title></link> in the Windows Server library.
trans-unit.target: Without single sign on, users are prompted for their credentials before they can use rights-protected content.<html></html><html></html>For instructions to configure federation by using Active Directory Federation Services (AD FS) between Active Directory Domain Services and Azure Active Directory, see the <link><linkText>Checklist: Use AD FS to implement and manage single sign-on</linkText><title></title></link> in the Windows Server library.

trans-unit.source: A minimum of two member computers on which to install the RMS connector:<html></html><html></html>A 64-bit physical or virtual computer running one of the following operating systems: Windows Server 2012 R2, Windows Server 2012, or Windows Server 2008 R2.<html></html><html></html>At least 1 GB of RAM.<html></html><html></html>A minimum of 64 GB of disk space<html></html><html></html>At least one network interface.<html></html><html></html>Access to the Internet via a firewall (or web proxy) that does not require authentication.<html></html><html></html>Must be in a forest or domain that trusts other forests in the organization that contain installations of Exchange or SharePoint servers that you want to use with the RMS connector.
trans-unit.target: A minimum of two member computers on which to install the RMS connector:<html></html><html></html>A 64-bit physical or virtual computer running one of the following operating systems: Windows Server 2012 R2, Windows Server 2012, or Windows Server 2008 R2.<html></html><html></html>At least 1 GB of RAM.<html></html><html></html>A minimum of 64 GB of disk space<html></html><html></html>At least one network interface.<html></html><html></html>Access to the Internet via a firewall (or web proxy) that does not require authentication.<html></html><html></html>Must be in a forest or domain that trusts other forests in the organization that contain installations of Exchange or SharePoint servers that you want to use with the RMS connector.

trans-unit.source: For fault tolerance and high availability, you must install the RMS connector on a minimum of two computers.Tip: If you are using Outlook Web Access or mobile devices that use Exchange ActiveSync IRM and it is critical that you maintain access to emails and attachments that are protected by Azure RMS, we recommend that you deploy a load-balanced group of connector servers to ensure high availability.You do not need dedicated servers to run the connector but you must install it on a separate computer from the servers that will use the connector.Important: Do not install the connector on a computer that runs Exchange Server, SharePoint Server, or a file server that is configured for file classification infrastructure if you want to use the functionality from these services with Azure RMS.
trans-unit.target: For fault tolerance and high availability, you must install the RMS connector on a minimum of two computers.Tip: If you are using Outlook Web Access or mobile devices that use Exchange ActiveSync IRM and it is critical that you maintain access to emails and attachments that are protected by Azure RMS, we recommend that you deploy a load-balanced group of connector servers to ensure high availability.You do not need dedicated servers to run the connector but you must install it on a separate computer from the servers that will use the connector.Important: Do not install the connector on a computer that runs Exchange Server, SharePoint Server, or a file server that is configured for file classification infrastructure if you want to use the functionality from these services with Azure RMS.

trans-unit.source: Also, do not install this connector on a domain controller.
trans-unit.target: Also, do not install this connector on a domain controller.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Installing the RMS connector
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Installing the RMS connector

trans-unit.source: After you have confirmed the prerequisites in the preceding section, use the following instructions to install the RMS connector:
trans-unit.target: After you have confirmed the prerequisites in the preceding section, use the following instructions to install the RMS connector:

trans-unit.source: Identify the computers (minimum of two) that will run the RMS connector.
trans-unit.target: Identify the computers (minimum of two) that will run the RMS connector.

trans-unit.source: They must meet the minimum specification listed in the preceding section.
trans-unit.target: They must meet the minimum specification listed in the preceding section.

trans-unit.source: You will install a single RMS connector (consisting of multiple servers for high availability) per tenant (Office 365 tenant or Azure AD tenant).
trans-unit.target: You will install a single RMS connector (consisting of multiple servers for high availability) per tenant (Office 365 tenant or Azure AD tenant).

trans-unit.source: Unlike Active Directory RMS, you do not have to install an RMS connector in each forest.
trans-unit.target: Unlike Active Directory RMS, you do not have to install an RMS connector in each forest.

trans-unit.source: Download the source files for the RMS connector from the <link><linkText>Microsoft Download Center</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Download the source files for the RMS connector from the <link><linkText>Microsoft Download Center</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: To install the RMS connector, download RMSConnectorSetup.exe.
trans-unit.target: To install the RMS connector, download RMSConnectorSetup.exe.

trans-unit.source: In addition:
trans-unit.target: In addition:

trans-unit.source: If you later want to configure the connector from a 32-bit computer, also download RMSConnectorAdminToolSetup_x86.exe.
trans-unit.target: If you later want to configure the connector from a 32-bit computer, also download RMSConnectorAdminToolSetup_x86.exe.

trans-unit.source: If you want to use the server configuration tool for the RMS connector, to automate the configuration of registry settings on you on-premises servers, also download GenConnectorConfig.ps1.
trans-unit.target: If you want to use the server configuration tool for the RMS connector, to automate the configuration of registry settings on you on-premises servers, also download GenConnectorConfig.ps1.

trans-unit.source: On the computer on which you want to install the RMS connector, run RMSConnectorSetup.exe with Administrator privileges.
trans-unit.target: On the computer on which you want to install the RMS connector, run RMSConnectorSetup.exe with Administrator privileges.

trans-unit.source: On the Welcome page of the Microsoft Rights Management Connector Setup page, select Install Microsoft Rights Management connector on the computer, and then click Next.
trans-unit.target: On the Welcome page of the Microsoft Rights Management Connector Setup page, select Install Microsoft Rights Management connector on the computer, and then click Next.

trans-unit.source: Read and agree to the RMS connector license terms, and then click Next.
trans-unit.target: Read and agree to the RMS connector license terms, and then click Next.

trans-unit.source: To continue, enter an account and password to configure the RMS connector.
trans-unit.target: To continue, enter an account and password to configure the RMS connector.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Entering credentials
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Entering credentials

trans-unit.source: Before you can configure the RMS connector, you must enter credentials for an account that has sufficient privileges to configure the RMS connector.
trans-unit.target: Before you can configure the RMS connector, you must enter credentials for an account that has sufficient privileges to configure the RMS connector.

trans-unit.source: In addition, if you have implemented <link><linkText>onboarding controls</linkText><title></title></link>, make sure that the account you specify is able to protect content.
trans-unit.target: In addition, if you have implemented <link><linkText>onboarding controls</linkText><title></title></link>, make sure that the account you specify is able to protect content.

trans-unit.source: For example, if you restricted the ability to protect content to the “IT department” group, the account that you specify here must be a member of that group.
trans-unit.target: For example, if you restricted the ability to protect content to the “IT department” group, the account that you specify here must be a member of that group.

trans-unit.source: If not, you will see the error message: **The attempt to discover the location of the administration service and organization failed.
trans-unit.target: If not, you will see the error message: **The attempt to discover the location of the administration service and organization failed.

trans-unit.source: Make sure Microsoft Rights Management service is enabled for your organization.**
trans-unit.target: Make sure Microsoft Rights Management service is enabled for your organization.**

trans-unit.source: You can use an account that has one of the following privileges:
trans-unit.target: You can use an account that has one of the following privileges:

trans-unit.source: Office 365 tenant administrator: An account that is a global admin for your Office 365 tenant.
trans-unit.target: Office 365 tenant administrator: An account that is a global admin for your Office 365 tenant.

trans-unit.source: Azure Rights Management global administrator: An account with administrator privileges for the Azure RMS tenant.
trans-unit.target: Azure Rights Management global administrator: An account with administrator privileges for the Azure RMS tenant.

trans-unit.source: Microsoft RMS connector Administrator: An account in Azure Active Directory that has been granted rights to install and administer the RMS connector for your organization.
trans-unit.target: Microsoft RMS connector Administrator: An account in Azure Active Directory that has been granted rights to install and administer the RMS connector for your organization.

trans-unit.source: If you want to use the Microsoft RMS connector Administrator account, you must first do the following to assign the RMS connector administrator role:
trans-unit.target: If you want to use the Microsoft RMS connector Administrator account, you must first do the following to assign the RMS connector administrator role:

trans-unit.source: 1. On the same computer, download and install Windows PowerShell for Rights Management.
trans-unit.target: 1. On the same computer, download and install Windows PowerShell for Rights Management.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <link><linkText>Installing Windows PowerShell for Azure Rights Management</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <link><linkText>Installing Windows PowerShell for Azure Rights Management</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Start Windows PowerShell with the Run as administrator command, and connect to the Azure RMS service by using the Connect-AadrmService command:
trans-unit.target: Start Windows PowerShell with the Run as administrator command, and connect to the Azure RMS service by using the Connect-AadrmService command:

trans-unit.source: Connect-AadrmService //provide Office 365 tenant administrator or Azure RMS global administrator credentials
trans-unit.target: Connect-AadrmService //provide Office 365 tenant administrator or Azure RMS global administrator credentials

trans-unit.source: 2. Then run the <link><linkText>Add-AadrmRoleBasedAdministrator</linkText><title></title></link> command, using just one of the following parameters:
trans-unit.target: 2. Then run the <link><linkText>Add-AadrmRoleBasedAdministrator</linkText><title></title></link> command, using just one of the following parameters:

trans-unit.source: Add-AadrmRoleBasedAdministrator -EmailAddress <html></html> -Role "ConnectorAdministrator"
trans-unit.target: Add-AadrmRoleBasedAdministrator -EmailAddress <html></html> -Role "ConnectorAdministrator"

trans-unit.source: Add-AadrmRoleBasedAdministrator -ObjectId <html></html> -Role "ConnectorAdministrator"
trans-unit.target: Add-AadrmRoleBasedAdministrator -ObjectId <html></html> -Role "ConnectorAdministrator"

trans-unit.source: Add-AadrmRoleBasedAdministrator -SecurityGroupDisplayName <html></html> -Role "ConnectorAdministrator"
trans-unit.target: Add-AadrmRoleBasedAdministrator -SecurityGroupDisplayName <html></html> -Role "ConnectorAdministrator"

trans-unit.source: For example, type: Add-AadrmRoleBasedAdministrator -EmailAddress melisa@contoso.com -Role " ConnectorAdministrator "
trans-unit.target: For example, type: Add-AadrmRoleBasedAdministrator -EmailAddress melisa@contoso.com -Role " ConnectorAdministrator "

trans-unit.source: Although these commands use the ConnectorAdministrator role, you could also use the GlobalAdministrator role here, as well.
trans-unit.target: Although these commands use the ConnectorAdministrator role, you could also use the GlobalAdministrator role here, as well.

trans-unit.source: During the RMS connector installation process, all prerequisite software is validated and installed, Internet Information Services (IIS) is installed if not already present, and the connector software is installed and configured.
trans-unit.target: During the RMS connector installation process, all prerequisite software is validated and installed, Internet Information Services (IIS) is installed if not already present, and the connector software is installed and configured.

trans-unit.source: In addition, Azure RMS is prepared for configuration by creating the following:
trans-unit.target: In addition, Azure RMS is prepared for configuration by creating the following:

trans-unit.source: An empty table of servers that are authorized to use the connector to communicate with Azure RMS.
trans-unit.target: An empty table of servers that are authorized to use the connector to communicate with Azure RMS.

trans-unit.source: You will add servers to this table later.
trans-unit.target: You will add servers to this table later.

trans-unit.source: A set of security tokens for the connector, which authorize operations with Azure RMS.
trans-unit.target: A set of security tokens for the connector, which authorize operations with Azure RMS.

trans-unit.source: These tokens are downloaded from Azure RMS and installed on the local computer in the registry.
trans-unit.target: These tokens are downloaded from Azure RMS and installed on the local computer in the registry.

trans-unit.source: They are protected by using the data protection application programming interface (DPAPI) and the Local System account credentials.
trans-unit.target: They are protected by using the data protection application programming interface (DPAPI) and the Local System account credentials.

trans-unit.source: On the final page of the wizard, do the following, and then click Finish:
trans-unit.target: On the final page of the wizard, do the following, and then click Finish:

trans-unit.source: If this is the first connector that you have installed, do not select Launch connector administrator console to authorize servers at this time.
trans-unit.target: If this is the first connector that you have installed, do not select Launch connector administrator console to authorize servers at this time.

trans-unit.source: You will select this option after you have installed your second (or final) RMS connector.
trans-unit.target: You will select this option after you have installed your second (or final) RMS connector.

trans-unit.source: Instead, run the wizard again on at least one other computer.
trans-unit.target: Instead, run the wizard again on at least one other computer.

trans-unit.source: You must install a minimum of two connectors.
trans-unit.target: You must install a minimum of two connectors.

trans-unit.source: If you have installed your second (or final) connector, select Launch connector administrator console to authorize servers.
trans-unit.target: If you have installed your second (or final) connector, select Launch connector administrator console to authorize servers.

trans-unit.source: At this point, there is a verification test that you can perform to test whether the web services for the RMS connector are operational:
trans-unit.target: At this point, there is a verification test that you can perform to test whether the web services for the RMS connector are operational:

trans-unit.source: - From a web browser, connect to http:///_wmcs/certification/servercertification.asmx, replacing with the server address or name that has the RMS connector installed.
trans-unit.target: - From a web browser, connect to http:///_wmcs/certification/servercertification.asmx, replacing with the server address or name that has the RMS connector installed.

trans-unit.source: A successful connection displays a ServerCertificationWebService page.
trans-unit.target: A successful connection displays a ServerCertificationWebService page.

trans-unit.source: If you need to uninstall the RMS connector, run the wizard again and select the uninstall option.
trans-unit.target: If you need to uninstall the RMS connector, run the wizard again and select the uninstall option.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Authorizing servers to use the RMS connector
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Authorizing servers to use the RMS connector

trans-unit.source: When you have installed the RMS connector on at least two computers, you are ready to authorize the servers and services that you want to use the RMS connector.
trans-unit.target: When you have installed the RMS connector on at least two computers, you are ready to authorize the servers and services that you want to use the RMS connector.

trans-unit.source: For example, servers running Exchange Server 2013 or SharePoint Server 2013.
trans-unit.target: For example, servers running Exchange Server 2013 or SharePoint Server 2013.

trans-unit.source: To define these servers, run the RMS connector administration tool and add entries to the list of allowed servers.
trans-unit.target: To define these servers, run the RMS connector administration tool and add entries to the list of allowed servers.

trans-unit.source: You can run this tool when you select Launch connector administration console to authorize servers at the end of the Microsoft Rights Management connector Setup wizard, or you can run it separately from the wizard.
trans-unit.target: You can run this tool when you select Launch connector administration console to authorize servers at the end of the Microsoft Rights Management connector Setup wizard, or you can run it separately from the wizard.

trans-unit.source: When you authorize these servers, be aware of the following considerations:
trans-unit.target: When you authorize these servers, be aware of the following considerations:

trans-unit.source: Servers that you add will be granted special privileges.
trans-unit.target: Servers that you add will be granted special privileges.

trans-unit.source: All accounts that you specify for the Exchange Server role in the connector configuration will be granted the <link><linkText>super user role</linkText><title></title></link> in Azure RMS, which gives them access to all content for this RMS tenant.
trans-unit.target: All accounts that you specify for the Exchange Server role in the connector configuration will be granted the <link><linkText>super user role</linkText><title></title></link> in Azure RMS, which gives them access to all content for this RMS tenant.

trans-unit.source: The super user feature is automatically enabled at this point, if necessary.
trans-unit.target: The super user feature is automatically enabled at this point, if necessary.

trans-unit.source: To avoid the security risk of elevation of privileges, be careful to specify only the accounts that are used by your organization’s Exchange servers.
trans-unit.target: To avoid the security risk of elevation of privileges, be careful to specify only the accounts that are used by your organization’s Exchange servers.

trans-unit.source: All servers configured as SharePoint servers or file servers that use FCI will be granted regular user privileges.
trans-unit.target: All servers configured as SharePoint servers or file servers that use FCI will be granted regular user privileges.

trans-unit.source: You can add multiple servers as a single entry by specifying an Active Directory security or distribution group, or a service account that is used by more than one server.
trans-unit.target: You can add multiple servers as a single entry by specifying an Active Directory security or distribution group, or a service account that is used by more than one server.

trans-unit.source: When you use this configuration, the group of servers will share the same RMS certificates and will all be considered owners for content that any of them have protected.
trans-unit.target: When you use this configuration, the group of servers will share the same RMS certificates and will all be considered owners for content that any of them have protected.

trans-unit.source: To minimize administrative overheads, we recommend that you use this configuration of a single group rather than individual servers to authorize your organization’s Exchange servers or a SharePoint server farm.
trans-unit.target: To minimize administrative overheads, we recommend that you use this configuration of a single group rather than individual servers to authorize your organization’s Exchange servers or a SharePoint server farm.

trans-unit.source: On the Servers allowed to utilize the connector page, click Add.
trans-unit.target: On the Servers allowed to utilize the connector page, click Add.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Add a server to the list of allowed servers
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Add a server to the list of allowed servers

trans-unit.source: On the Allow a server to utilize the connector page, enter the name of the object, or browse to identify the object to authorize.
trans-unit.target: On the Allow a server to utilize the connector page, enter the name of the object, or browse to identify the object to authorize.

trans-unit.source: It is important that you authorize the correct object.
trans-unit.target: It is important that you authorize the correct object.

trans-unit.source: For a server to use the connector, the account that runs the on-premises service (for example, Exchange or SharePoint) must be selected for authorization.
trans-unit.target: For a server to use the connector, the account that runs the on-premises service (for example, Exchange or SharePoint) must be selected for authorization.

trans-unit.source: For example, if the service is running as a configured service account, add the name of that service account to the list.
trans-unit.target: For example, if the service is running as a configured service account, add the name of that service account to the list.

trans-unit.source: If the service is running as Local System, add the name of the computer object (for example, SERVERNAME$).
trans-unit.target: If the service is running as Local System, add the name of the computer object (for example, SERVERNAME$).

trans-unit.source: As a best practice, create a group that contains these accounts and specify the group instead of individual server names.
trans-unit.target: As a best practice, create a group that contains these accounts and specify the group instead of individual server names.

trans-unit.source: More information about the different server roles:
trans-unit.target: More information about the different server roles:

trans-unit.source: For servers that run Exchange: You must specify a security group and you can use the default group (Exchange Servers) that Exchange automatically creates and maintains of all Exchange servers in the forest.
trans-unit.target: For servers that run Exchange: You must specify a security group and you can use the default group (Exchange Servers) that Exchange automatically creates and maintains of all Exchange servers in the forest.

trans-unit.source: For servers that run SharePoint:
trans-unit.target: For servers that run SharePoint:

trans-unit.source: If a SharePoint 2010 server is configured to run as Local System (it's not using a service account), manually create a security group in Active Directory Domain Services, and add the computer name object for the server in this configuration to this group.
trans-unit.target: If a SharePoint 2010 server is configured to run as Local System (it's not using a service account), manually create a security group in Active Directory Domain Services, and add the computer name object for the server in this configuration to this group.

trans-unit.source: If a SharePoint server is configured to use a service account (the recommended practice for SharePoint 2010 and the only option for SharePoint 2013), do the following:
trans-unit.target: If a SharePoint server is configured to use a service account (the recommended practice for SharePoint 2010 and the only option for SharePoint 2013), do the following:

trans-unit.source: Add the service account that runs the SharePoint Central Administration service to enable SharePoint to be configured from its administrator console.
trans-unit.target: Add the service account that runs the SharePoint Central Administration service to enable SharePoint to be configured from its administrator console.

trans-unit.source: Add the account that is configured for the SharePoint App Pool.
trans-unit.target: Add the account that is configured for the SharePoint App Pool.

trans-unit.source: If these two accounts are different, consider creating a single group that contains both accounts to minimize the administrative overheads.
trans-unit.target: If these two accounts are different, consider creating a single group that contains both accounts to minimize the administrative overheads.

trans-unit.source: For file servers that use File Classification Infrastructure, the associated services run as the Local System account, so you must authorize the computer account for the file servers (for example, SERVERNAME$) or a group that contains those computer accounts.
trans-unit.target: For file servers that use File Classification Infrastructure, the associated services run as the Local System account, so you must authorize the computer account for the file servers (for example, SERVERNAME$) or a group that contains those computer accounts.

trans-unit.source: When you have finished adding servers to the list, click Close.
trans-unit.target: When you have finished adding servers to the list, click Close.

trans-unit.source: If you haven’t already done so, you must now configure load balancing for the servers that have the RMS connector installed, and consider whether to use HTTPS for the connections between these servers and the servers that you have just authorized.
trans-unit.target: If you haven’t already done so, you must now configure load balancing for the servers that have the RMS connector installed, and consider whether to use HTTPS for the connections between these servers and the servers that you have just authorized.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Configuring load balancing and high availability
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Configuring load balancing and high availability

trans-unit.source: After you have installed the second or final instance of the RMS connector, define a connector URL server name and configure a load balancing system.
trans-unit.target: After you have installed the second or final instance of the RMS connector, define a connector URL server name and configure a load balancing system.

trans-unit.source: The connector URL server name can be any name under a namespace that you control.
trans-unit.target: The connector URL server name can be any name under a namespace that you control.

trans-unit.source: For example, you could create an entry in your DNS system for rmsconnector.contoso.com and configure this entry to use an IP address in your load balancing system.
trans-unit.target: For example, you could create an entry in your DNS system for rmsconnector.contoso.com and configure this entry to use an IP address in your load balancing system.

trans-unit.source: There are no special requirements for this name and it doesn’t need to be configured on the connector servers themselves.
trans-unit.target: There are no special requirements for this name and it doesn’t need to be configured on the connector servers themselves.

trans-unit.source: Unless your Exchange and SharePoint servers are going to be communicating with the connector over the Internet, this name doesn’t have to resolve on the Internet.
trans-unit.target: Unless your Exchange and SharePoint servers are going to be communicating with the connector over the Internet, this name doesn’t have to resolve on the Internet.

trans-unit.source: We recommend that you don’t change this name after you have configured Exchange or SharePoint servers to use the connector, because you have to then clear these servers of all IRM configurations and then reconfigure them.
trans-unit.target: We recommend that you don’t change this name after you have configured Exchange or SharePoint servers to use the connector, because you have to then clear these servers of all IRM configurations and then reconfigure them.

trans-unit.source: After the name is created in DNS and is configured for an IP address, configure load balancing for that address, which directs traffic to the connector servers.
trans-unit.target: After the name is created in DNS and is configured for an IP address, configure load balancing for that address, which directs traffic to the connector servers.

trans-unit.source: You can use any IP-based load balancer for this purpose, which includes the Network Load Balancing (NLB) feature in Windows Server.
trans-unit.target: You can use any IP-based load balancer for this purpose, which includes the Network Load Balancing (NLB) feature in Windows Server.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <link><linkText>Load Balancing Deployment Guide</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <link><linkText>Load Balancing Deployment Guide</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Use the following settings to configure the NLB cluster:
trans-unit.target: Use the following settings to configure the NLB cluster:

trans-unit.source: Ports: 80 (for HTTP) or 443 (for HTTPS)
trans-unit.target: Ports: 80 (for HTTP) or 443 (for HTTPS)

trans-unit.source: For more information about whether to use HTTP or HTTPS, see the next section.
trans-unit.target: For more information about whether to use HTTP or HTTPS, see the next section.

trans-unit.source: Affinity: None
trans-unit.target: Affinity: None

trans-unit.source: Distribution method: Equal
trans-unit.target: Distribution method: Equal

trans-unit.source: This name that you define for the load-balanced system (for the servers running the RMS connector service) is your organization’s RMS connector name that you will use later, when you configure the on-premises servers to use Azure RMS.
trans-unit.target: This name that you define for the load-balanced system (for the servers running the RMS connector service) is your organization’s RMS connector name that you will use later, when you configure the on-premises servers to use Azure RMS.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Configuring the RMS connector to use HTTPS
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Configuring the RMS connector to use HTTPS

trans-unit.source: This configuration step is optional, but recommended for additional security.
trans-unit.target: This configuration step is optional, but recommended for additional security.

trans-unit.source: Although the use of TLS or SSL is optional for the RMS connector, we recommend it for any HTTP-based security-sensitive service.
trans-unit.target: Although the use of TLS or SSL is optional for the RMS connector, we recommend it for any HTTP-based security-sensitive service.

trans-unit.source: This configuration authenticates the servers running the connector to your Exchange and SharePoint servers that use the connector.
trans-unit.target: This configuration authenticates the servers running the connector to your Exchange and SharePoint servers that use the connector.

trans-unit.source: In addition, all data that is sent from these servers to the connector is encrypted.
trans-unit.target: In addition, all data that is sent from these servers to the connector is encrypted.

trans-unit.source: To enable the RMS connector to use TLS, on each server that runs the RMS connector, install a server authentication certificate that contains the name that you will use for the connector.
trans-unit.target: To enable the RMS connector to use TLS, on each server that runs the RMS connector, install a server authentication certificate that contains the name that you will use for the connector.

trans-unit.source: For example, if your RMS connector name that you defined in DNS is rmsconnector.contoso.com, deploy a server authentication certificate that contains rmsconnector.contoso.com in the certificate subject as the common name.
trans-unit.target: For example, if your RMS connector name that you defined in DNS is rmsconnector.contoso.com, deploy a server authentication certificate that contains rmsconnector.contoso.com in the certificate subject as the common name.

trans-unit.source: Or, specify rmsconnector.contoso.com in the certificate alternative name as the DNS value.
trans-unit.target: Or, specify rmsconnector.contoso.com in the certificate alternative name as the DNS value.

trans-unit.source: The certificate does not have to include the name of the server.
trans-unit.target: The certificate does not have to include the name of the server.

trans-unit.source: Then in IIS, bind this certificate to the Default Web Site.
trans-unit.target: Then in IIS, bind this certificate to the Default Web Site.

trans-unit.source: If you use the HTTPS option, ensure that all servers that run the connector have a valid server authentication certificate that chains to a root CA that your Exchange and SharePoint servers trust.
trans-unit.target: If you use the HTTPS option, ensure that all servers that run the connector have a valid server authentication certificate that chains to a root CA that your Exchange and SharePoint servers trust.

trans-unit.source: In addition, if the certification authority (CA) that issued the certificates for the connector servers publishes a certificate revocation list (CRL), the Exchange and SharePoint servers must be able to download this CRL.
trans-unit.target: In addition, if the certification authority (CA) that issued the certificates for the connector servers publishes a certificate revocation list (CRL), the Exchange and SharePoint servers must be able to download this CRL.

trans-unit.source: You can use the following information and resources to help you request and install a server authentication certificate, and to bind this certificate to the Default Web Site in IIS:
trans-unit.target: You can use the following information and resources to help you request and install a server authentication certificate, and to bind this certificate to the Default Web Site in IIS:

trans-unit.source: - If you use Active Directory Certificate Services (AD CS) and an enterprise certification authority (CA) to deploy these server authentication certificates, you can duplicate and then use the Web Server certificate template.
trans-unit.target: - If you use Active Directory Certificate Services (AD CS) and an enterprise certification authority (CA) to deploy these server authentication certificates, you can duplicate and then use the Web Server certificate template.

trans-unit.source: This certificate template uses Supplied in the request for the certificate subject name, which means that you can provide the FQDN of the RMS connector name for the certificate subject name or subject alternative name when you request the certificate.
trans-unit.target: This certificate template uses Supplied in the request for the certificate subject name, which means that you can provide the FQDN of the RMS connector name for the certificate subject name or subject alternative name when you request the certificate.

trans-unit.source: - If you use a stand-alone CA or purchase this certificate from another company, see <link><linkText>Configuring Internet Server Certificates (IIS 7)</linkText><title></title></link> in the <link><linkText>Web Server (IIS)</linkText><title></title></link> documentation library on TechNet.
trans-unit.target: - If you use a stand-alone CA or purchase this certificate from another company, see <link><linkText>Configuring Internet Server Certificates (IIS 7)</linkText><title></title></link> in the <link><linkText>Web Server (IIS)</linkText><title></title></link> documentation library on TechNet.

trans-unit.source: - To configure IIS to use the certificate, see <link><linkText>Add a Binding to a Site (IIS 7)</linkText><title></title></link> in the in the <link><linkText>Web Server (IIS)</linkText><title></title></link> documentation library on TechNet.
trans-unit.target: - To configure IIS to use the certificate, see <link><linkText>Add a Binding to a Site (IIS 7)</linkText><title></title></link> in the in the <link><linkText>Web Server (IIS)</linkText><title></title></link> documentation library on TechNet.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Configuring the RMS connector for a web proxy server
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Configuring the RMS connector for a web proxy server

trans-unit.source: If your connector servers are installed in a network that does not have direct Internet connectivity and requires manual configuration of a web proxy server for outbound Internet access, you must configure the registry on these servers for the RMS connector.
trans-unit.target: If your connector servers are installed in a network that does not have direct Internet connectivity and requires manual configuration of a web proxy server for outbound Internet access, you must configure the registry on these servers for the RMS connector.

trans-unit.source: To configure the RMS connector to use a web proxy server
trans-unit.target: To configure the RMS connector to use a web proxy server

trans-unit.source: On each server running the RMS connector, open a registry editor, such as Regedit.
trans-unit.target: On each server running the RMS connector, open a registry editor, such as Regedit.

trans-unit.source: Navigate to HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\AADRM\Connector
trans-unit.target: Navigate to HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\AADRM\Connector

trans-unit.source: Add the string value of ProxyAddress and then set the Data for this value to be http://:
trans-unit.target: Add the string value of ProxyAddress and then set the Data for this value to be http://:

trans-unit.source: For example: http://proxyserver.contoso.com:8080
trans-unit.target: For example: http://proxyserver.contoso.com:8080

trans-unit.source: Close the registry editor, and then restart the server or perform an IISReset command to restart IIS.
trans-unit.target: Close the registry editor, and then restart the server or perform an IISReset command to restart IIS.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Installing the RMS connector administration tool on administrative computers
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Installing the RMS connector administration tool on administrative computers

trans-unit.source: You can run the RMS connector administration tool from a computer that does not have the RMS connector installed, if that computer meets the following requirements:
trans-unit.target: You can run the RMS connector administration tool from a computer that does not have the RMS connector installed, if that computer meets the following requirements:

trans-unit.source: A physical or virtual computer running Windows Server 2012 or Windows Server 2012 R2 (all editions), Windows Server 2008 R2 or Windows Server 2008 R2 Service Pack 1 (all editions), Windows 8.1, Windows 8, or Windows 7.
trans-unit.target: A physical or virtual computer running Windows Server 2012 or Windows Server 2012 R2 (all editions), Windows Server 2008 R2 or Windows Server 2008 R2 Service Pack 1 (all editions), Windows 8.1, Windows 8, or Windows 7.

trans-unit.source: At least 1 GB of RAM.
trans-unit.target: At least 1 GB of RAM.

trans-unit.source: A minimum of 64 GB of disk space.
trans-unit.target: A minimum of 64 GB of disk space.

trans-unit.source: At least one network interface.
trans-unit.target: At least one network interface.

trans-unit.source: Access to the Internet via a firewall (or web proxy).
trans-unit.target: Access to the Internet via a firewall (or web proxy).

trans-unit.source: To install the RMS connector administration tool, run the following files:
trans-unit.target: To install the RMS connector administration tool, run the following files:

trans-unit.source: For a 32-bit computer: RMSConnectorAdminToolSetup_x86.exe
trans-unit.target: For a 32-bit computer: RMSConnectorAdminToolSetup_x86.exe

trans-unit.source: For a 64-bit computer: RMSConnectorSetup.exe
trans-unit.target: For a 64-bit computer: RMSConnectorSetup.exe

trans-unit.source: If you haven’t already downloaded these files, you can do so from the <link><linkText>Microsoft Download Center</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: If you haven’t already downloaded these files, you can do so from the <link><linkText>Microsoft Download Center</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Configuring servers to use the RMS connector
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Configuring servers to use the RMS connector

trans-unit.source: After you have installed and configured the RMS connector, you are ready to configure your on-premises servers that will use Rights Management and connect to Azure RMS by using the connector.
trans-unit.target: After you have installed and configured the RMS connector, you are ready to configure your on-premises servers that will use Rights Management and connect to Azure RMS by using the connector.

trans-unit.source: This means configuring the following servers:
trans-unit.target: This means configuring the following servers:

trans-unit.source: For Exchange 2013: Client access servers and mailbox servers
trans-unit.target: For Exchange 2013: Client access servers and mailbox servers

trans-unit.source: For Exchange 2010: Client access servers and hub transport servers
trans-unit.target: For Exchange 2010: Client access servers and hub transport servers

trans-unit.source: For SharePoint: Front-end SharePoint webservers, including those hosting the Central Administration server
trans-unit.target: For SharePoint: Front-end SharePoint webservers, including those hosting the Central Administration server

trans-unit.source: For File Classification Infrastructure: Windows Server computers that have installed File Resource Manager
trans-unit.target: For File Classification Infrastructure: Windows Server computers that have installed File Resource Manager

trans-unit.source: This configuration requires registry settings.
trans-unit.target: This configuration requires registry settings.

trans-unit.source: To do this, you have two options:
trans-unit.target: To do this, you have two options:

trans-unit.source: Configuration option
trans-unit.target: Configuration option

trans-unit.source: Advantages
trans-unit.target: Advantages

trans-unit.source: Disadvantages
trans-unit.target: Disadvantages

trans-unit.source: Automatically by using the server configuration tool for Microsoft RMS connector
trans-unit.target: Automatically by using the server configuration tool for Microsoft RMS connector

trans-unit.source: No direct editing of the registry.
trans-unit.target: No direct editing of the registry.

trans-unit.source: This is automated for you by using a script.<html></html><html></html>No need to run a Windows PowerShell cmdlet to obtain your Microsoft RMS URL.<html></html><html></html>The prerequisites are automatically checked for you (but not automatically remediated) if you run it locally.
trans-unit.target: This is automated for you by using a script.<html></html><html></html>No need to run a Windows PowerShell cmdlet to obtain your Microsoft RMS URL.<html></html><html></html>The prerequisites are automatically checked for you (but not automatically remediated) if you run it locally.

trans-unit.source: When you run the tool, you must make a connection to a server that is already running the RMS connector.
trans-unit.target: When you run the tool, you must make a connection to a server that is already running the RMS connector.

trans-unit.source: |Manually by editing the registry|No connectivity to a server running the RMS connector is required.|More administrative overheads that are error-prone.<html></html><html></html>You must obtain your Microsoft RMS URL, which requires you to run a Windows PowerShell command.<html></html><html></html>You must always make all the prerequisites checks yourself.|
trans-unit.target: |Manually by editing the registry|No connectivity to a server running the RMS connector is required.|More administrative overheads that are error-prone.<html></html><html></html>You must obtain your Microsoft RMS URL, which requires you to run a Windows PowerShell command.<html></html><html></html>You must always make all the prerequisites checks yourself.|

trans-unit.source: In both cases, you must manually install any prerequisites and configure Exchange, SharePoint, and File Classification Infrastructure to use Rights Management.
trans-unit.target: In both cases, you must manually install any prerequisites and configure Exchange, SharePoint, and File Classification Infrastructure to use Rights Management.

trans-unit.source: For most organizations, automatic configuration by using the server configuration tool for Microsoft RMS connector will be the better option, because it provides greater efficiency and reliability than manual configuration.
trans-unit.target: For most organizations, automatic configuration by using the server configuration tool for Microsoft RMS connector will be the better option, because it provides greater efficiency and reliability than manual configuration.

trans-unit.source: After making the configuration changes on these servers, you must restart them if they are running Exchange or SharePoint and previously configured to use AD RMS.
trans-unit.target: After making the configuration changes on these servers, you must restart them if they are running Exchange or SharePoint and previously configured to use AD RMS.

trans-unit.source: There is no need to restart these servers if you are configuring them for Rights Management for the first time.
trans-unit.target: There is no need to restart these servers if you are configuring them for Rights Management for the first time.

trans-unit.source: You must always restart the file server that is configured to use File Classification Infrastructure after you make these configuration changes.
trans-unit.target: You must always restart the file server that is configured to use File Classification Infrastructure after you make these configuration changes.

trans-unit.source: How to use the server configuration tool for Microsoft RMS connector
trans-unit.target: How to use the server configuration tool for Microsoft RMS connector

trans-unit.source: If you haven’t already downloaded the script for the server configuration tool for Microsoft RMS connector (GenConnectorConfig.ps1), download it from the <link><linkText>Microsoft Download Center</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: If you haven’t already downloaded the script for the server configuration tool for Microsoft RMS connector (GenConnectorConfig.ps1), download it from the <link><linkText>Microsoft Download Center</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Save the GenConnectorConfig.ps1 file on the computer where you will run the tool.
trans-unit.target: Save the GenConnectorConfig.ps1 file on the computer where you will run the tool.

trans-unit.source: If you will run the tool locally, this must be the server that you want to configure to communicate with the RMS connector.
trans-unit.target: If you will run the tool locally, this must be the server that you want to configure to communicate with the RMS connector.

trans-unit.source: Otherwise, you can save it on any computer.
trans-unit.target: Otherwise, you can save it on any computer.

trans-unit.source: Decide how to run the tool:
trans-unit.target: Decide how to run the tool:

trans-unit.source: Locally: You can run the tool interactively, from the server to be configured to communicate with the RMS connector.
trans-unit.target: Locally: You can run the tool interactively, from the server to be configured to communicate with the RMS connector.

trans-unit.source: This is useful for a one-off configuration, such as a testing environment.
trans-unit.target: This is useful for a one-off configuration, such as a testing environment.

trans-unit.source: Software deployment: You can run the tool to produce registry files that you then deploy to one or more relevant servers by using a systems management application that supports software deployment, such as System Center Configuration Manager.
trans-unit.target: Software deployment: You can run the tool to produce registry files that you then deploy to one or more relevant servers by using a systems management application that supports software deployment, such as System Center Configuration Manager.

trans-unit.source: Group Policy: You can run the tool to produce a script that you give to an administrator who can create Group Policy objects for the servers to be configured.
trans-unit.target: Group Policy: You can run the tool to produce a script that you give to an administrator who can create Group Policy objects for the servers to be configured.

trans-unit.source: This script creates one Group Policy object for each server type to be configured, which the administrator can then assign to the relevant servers.
trans-unit.target: This script creates one Group Policy object for each server type to be configured, which the administrator can then assign to the relevant servers.

trans-unit.source: This tool configures the servers that will communicate with the RMS connector and that are listed at the beginning of this section.
trans-unit.target: This tool configures the servers that will communicate with the RMS connector and that are listed at the beginning of this section.

trans-unit.source: Do not run this tool on the servers that run the RMS connector.
trans-unit.target: Do not run this tool on the servers that run the RMS connector.

trans-unit.source: Start Windows PowerShell with the Run as an administrator option, and use the Get-help command to read instructions how to the use the tool for your chosen configuration method:
trans-unit.target: Start Windows PowerShell with the Run as an administrator option, and use the Get-help command to read instructions how to the use the tool for your chosen configuration method:

trans-unit.source: To run the script, you must enter the URL of the RMS connector for your organization.
trans-unit.target: To run the script, you must enter the URL of the RMS connector for your organization.

trans-unit.source: Enter the protocol prefix (HTTP:// or HTTPS://) and the name of the connector that you defined in DNS for the load balanced address of your connector.
trans-unit.target: Enter the protocol prefix (HTTP:// or HTTPS://) and the name of the connector that you defined in DNS for the load balanced address of your connector.

trans-unit.source: For example, https://connector.contoso.com.
trans-unit.target: For example, https://connector.contoso.com.

trans-unit.source: The tool then uses that URL to contact the servers running the RMS connector and obtain other parameters that are used to create the required configurations.
trans-unit.target: The tool then uses that URL to contact the servers running the RMS connector and obtain other parameters that are used to create the required configurations.

trans-unit.source: When you run this tool, make sure that you specify the name of the load-balanced RMS connector for your organization and not the name of a single server that runs the RMS connector service.
trans-unit.target: When you run this tool, make sure that you specify the name of the load-balanced RMS connector for your organization and not the name of a single server that runs the RMS connector service.

trans-unit.source: Use the following sections for specific information for each service type:
trans-unit.target: Use the following sections for specific information for each service type:

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Configuring an Exchange server to use the connector</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Configuring an Exchange server to use the connector</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Configuring a SharePoint server to use the connector</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Configuring a SharePoint server to use the connector</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Configuring a file server for File Classification Infrastructure to use the connector</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Configuring a file server for File Classification Infrastructure to use the connector</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: After these servers are configured to use the connector, client applications that are installed locally on these servers might not work with RMS.
trans-unit.target: After these servers are configured to use the connector, client applications that are installed locally on these servers might not work with RMS.

trans-unit.source: When this happens, it is because the applications try to use the connector rather than use RMS directly, which is not supported.
trans-unit.target: When this happens, it is because the applications try to use the connector rather than use RMS directly, which is not supported.

trans-unit.source: In addition, if Office 2010 is installed locally on an Exchange server, the client app’s IRM features might work from that computer after the server is configured to use the connector, but this is not supported.
trans-unit.target: In addition, if Office 2010 is installed locally on an Exchange server, the client app’s IRM features might work from that computer after the server is configured to use the connector, but this is not supported.

trans-unit.source: In both scenarios, you must install the client applications on separate computers that are not configured to use the connector.
trans-unit.target: In both scenarios, you must install the client applications on separate computers that are not configured to use the connector.

trans-unit.source: They will then correctly use RMS directly.
trans-unit.target: They will then correctly use RMS directly.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Configuring an Exchange server to use the connector
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Configuring an Exchange server to use the connector

trans-unit.source: The following Exchange roles communicate with the RMS connector:
trans-unit.target: The following Exchange roles communicate with the RMS connector:

trans-unit.source: For Exchange 2013: Client access server and mailbox server
trans-unit.target: For Exchange 2013: Client access server and mailbox server

trans-unit.source: For Exchange 2010: Client access server and hub transport server
trans-unit.target: For Exchange 2010: Client access server and hub transport server

trans-unit.source: To use the RMS connector, these servers running Exchange must be running one of the following software versions:
trans-unit.target: To use the RMS connector, these servers running Exchange must be running one of the following software versions:

trans-unit.source: Exchange Server 2013 with Exchange 2013 Cumulative Update 3
trans-unit.target: Exchange Server 2013 with Exchange 2013 Cumulative Update 3

trans-unit.source: Exchange Server 2010 with Exchange 2010 Service Pack 3 Rollup Update 6
trans-unit.target: Exchange Server 2010 with Exchange 2010 Service Pack 3 Rollup Update 6

trans-unit.source: You will also need to install on these servers, a version of the RMS client that includes support for RMS Cryptographic Mode 2.
trans-unit.target: You will also need to install on these servers, a version of the RMS client that includes support for RMS Cryptographic Mode 2.

trans-unit.source: The minimum version that is supported in Windows Server 2008 is included in the hotfix that you can download from <link><linkText>RSA key length is increased to 2048 bits for AD RMS in Windows Server 2008 R2 and in Windows Server 2008</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: The minimum version that is supported in Windows Server 2008 is included in the hotfix that you can download from <link><linkText>RSA key length is increased to 2048 bits for AD RMS in Windows Server 2008 R2 and in Windows Server 2008</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: The minimum version for Windows Server 2008 R2 can be downloaded from <link><linkText>RSA key length is increased to 2048 bits for AD RMS in Windows 7 or in Windows Server 2008 R2</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: The minimum version for Windows Server 2008 R2 can be downloaded from <link><linkText>RSA key length is increased to 2048 bits for AD RMS in Windows 7 or in Windows Server 2008 R2</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Windows Server 2012 and Windows Server 2012 R2 natively support Cryptographic Mode 2.
trans-unit.target: Windows Server 2012 and Windows Server 2012 R2 natively support Cryptographic Mode 2.

trans-unit.source: If these versions or later versions of Exchange and the RMS client are not installed, you will not be able to configure Exchange to use the connector.
trans-unit.target: If these versions or later versions of Exchange and the RMS client are not installed, you will not be able to configure Exchange to use the connector.

trans-unit.source: Check that these versions are installed before you continue.
trans-unit.target: Check that these versions are installed before you continue.

trans-unit.source: To configure Exchange servers to use the connector
trans-unit.target: To configure Exchange servers to use the connector

trans-unit.source: On the Exchange server roles that communicate with the RMS connector, do one of the following:
trans-unit.target: On the Exchange server roles that communicate with the RMS connector, do one of the following:

trans-unit.source: Run the server configuration tool for Microsoft RMS connector.
trans-unit.target: Run the server configuration tool for Microsoft RMS connector.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <link><linkText>How to use the server configuration tool for Microsoft RMS connector</linkText><title></title></link> in this topic.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <link><linkText>How to use the server configuration tool for Microsoft RMS connector</linkText><title></title></link> in this topic.

trans-unit.source: For example, to run the tool locally to configure a server running Exchange 2013:
trans-unit.target: For example, to run the tool locally to configure a server running Exchange 2013:

trans-unit.source: Make manual registry edits by using the tables in the following sections to manually add registry settings on the servers.
trans-unit.target: Make manual registry edits by using the tables in the following sections to manually add registry settings on the servers.

trans-unit.source: Enable IRM functionality in Exchange.
trans-unit.target: Enable IRM functionality in Exchange.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <link><linkText>Information Rights Management Procedures</linkText><title></title></link> in the Exchange library.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <link><linkText>Information Rights Management Procedures</linkText><title></title></link> in the Exchange library.

trans-unit.source: Use the tables in the following sections only if you want to manually add or check registry settings on these servers, which configures the servers to use the RMS connector.
trans-unit.target: Use the tables in the following sections only if you want to manually add or check registry settings on these servers, which configures the servers to use the RMS connector.

trans-unit.source: Instructions for when you use these tables:
trans-unit.target: Instructions for when you use these tables:

trans-unit.source: MicrosoftRMSURL is your organization’s Microsoft RMS service URL.
trans-unit.target: MicrosoftRMSURL is your organization’s Microsoft RMS service URL.

trans-unit.source: To find this value:
trans-unit.target: To find this value:

trans-unit.source: Run the <link><linkText>Get-AadrmConfiguration</linkText><title></title></link> cmdlet for Azure RMS.
trans-unit.target: Run the <link><linkText>Get-AadrmConfiguration</linkText><title></title></link> cmdlet for Azure RMS.

trans-unit.source: If you haven’t already installed the Windows PowerShell module for Azure RMS, see <link><linkText>Installing Windows PowerShell for Azure Rights Management</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: If you haven’t already installed the Windows PowerShell module for Azure RMS, see <link><linkText>Installing Windows PowerShell for Azure Rights Management</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: From the output, identify the LicensingIntranetDistributionPointUrl value.
trans-unit.target: From the output, identify the LicensingIntranetDistributionPointUrl value.

trans-unit.source: For example: LicensingIntranetDistributionPointUrl   : https://5c6bb73b-1038-4eec-863d-49bded473437.rms.na.aadrm.com/_wmcs/licensing
trans-unit.target: For example: LicensingIntranetDistributionPointUrl   : https://5c6bb73b-1038-4eec-863d-49bded473437.rms.na.aadrm.com/_wmcs/licensing

trans-unit.source: From the value, remove /_wmcs/licensing from this string.
trans-unit.target: From the value, remove /_wmcs/licensing from this string.

trans-unit.source: The remaining string is your Microsoft RMS URL.
trans-unit.target: The remaining string is your Microsoft RMS URL.

trans-unit.source: In our example, the Microsoft RMS URL would be the following value:
trans-unit.target: In our example, the Microsoft RMS URL would be the following value:

trans-unit.source: https://5c6bb73b-1038-4eec-863d-49bded473437.rms.na.aadrm.com
trans-unit.target: https://5c6bb73b-1038-4eec-863d-49bded473437.rms.na.aadrm.com

trans-unit.source: ConnectorFQDN is the load-balancing name that you defined in DNS for the connector.
trans-unit.target: ConnectorFQDN is the load-balancing name that you defined in DNS for the connector.

trans-unit.source: For example, rmsconnector.contoso.com.
trans-unit.target: For example, rmsconnector.contoso.com.

trans-unit.source: Use the HTTPS prefix for the connector URL if you have configured the connector to use HTTPS to communicate with your on-premises servers.
trans-unit.target: Use the HTTPS prefix for the connector URL if you have configured the connector to use HTTPS to communicate with your on-premises servers.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see the <link><linkText>Configuring the RMS connector to use HTTPS</linkText><title></title></link> section in this topic.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see the <link><linkText>Configuring the RMS connector to use HTTPS</linkText><title></title></link> section in this topic.

trans-unit.source: The Microsoft RMS URLs always use HTTPS.
trans-unit.target: The Microsoft RMS URLs always use HTTPS.
