trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Configuring a SharePoint server to use the connector
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Configuring a SharePoint server to use the connector

trans-unit.source: The following SharePoint roles communicate with the RMS connector:
trans-unit.target: The following SharePoint roles communicate with the RMS connector:

trans-unit.source: Front-end SharePoint webservers, including those hosting the Central Administration server
trans-unit.target: Front-end SharePoint webservers, including those hosting the Central Administration server

trans-unit.source: To use the RMS connector, these servers running SharePoint must be running one of the following software versions:
trans-unit.target: To use the RMS connector, these servers running SharePoint must be running one of the following software versions:

trans-unit.source: SharePoint Server 2013
trans-unit.target: SharePoint Server 2013

trans-unit.source: SharePoint Server 2010
trans-unit.target: SharePoint Server 2010

trans-unit.source: A SharePoint 2013 server must also be running a version of the MSIPC client 2.1 that is supported with the RMS connector.
trans-unit.target: A SharePoint 2013 server must also be running a version of the MSIPC client 2.1 that is supported with the RMS connector.

trans-unit.source: To make sure that you have a supported version, download the latest client from the <link><linkText>Microsoft Download Center</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: To make sure that you have a supported version, download the latest client from the <link><linkText>Microsoft Download Center</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: There are multiple versions of the MSIPC 2.1 client, so make sure that you have version 1.0.2004.0 or later.
trans-unit.target: There are multiple versions of the MSIPC 2.1 client, so make sure that you have version 1.0.2004.0 or later.

trans-unit.source: You can verify the client version by checking the version number of MSIPC.dll, which is located in \Program Files\Active Directory Rights Management Services Client 2.1.
trans-unit.target: You can verify the client version by checking the version number of MSIPC.dll, which is located in \Program Files\Active Directory Rights Management Services Client 2.1.

trans-unit.source: The properties dialog box shows the version number of the MSIPC 2.1 client.
trans-unit.target: The properties dialog box shows the version number of the MSIPC 2.1 client.

trans-unit.source: These servers running SharePoint 2010 must have installed a version of the MSDRM client that includes support for RMS Cryptographic Mode 2.
trans-unit.target: These servers running SharePoint 2010 must have installed a version of the MSDRM client that includes support for RMS Cryptographic Mode 2.

trans-unit.source: The minimum version that is supported in Windows Server 2008 is included in the hotfix that you can download from <link><linkText>RSA key length is increased to 2048 bits for AD RMS in Windows Server 2008 R2 and in Windows Server 2008</linkText><title></title></link>, and the minimum version for Windows Server 2008 R2 can be downloaded from <link><linkText>RSA key length is increased to 2048 bits for AD RMS in Windows 7 or in Windows Server 2008 R2</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: The minimum version that is supported in Windows Server 2008 is included in the hotfix that you can download from <link><linkText>RSA key length is increased to 2048 bits for AD RMS in Windows Server 2008 R2 and in Windows Server 2008</linkText><title></title></link>, and the minimum version for Windows Server 2008 R2 can be downloaded from <link><linkText>RSA key length is increased to 2048 bits for AD RMS in Windows 7 or in Windows Server 2008 R2</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Windows Server 2012 and Windows Server 2012 R2 natively support Cryptographic Mode 2.
trans-unit.target: Windows Server 2012 and Windows Server 2012 R2 natively support Cryptographic Mode 2.

trans-unit.source: To configure SharePoint servers to use the connector
trans-unit.target: To configure SharePoint servers to use the connector

trans-unit.source: On the SharePoint servers that communicate with the RMS connector, do one of the following:
trans-unit.target: On the SharePoint servers that communicate with the RMS connector, do one of the following:

trans-unit.source: Run the server configuration tool for Microsoft RMS connector.
trans-unit.target: Run the server configuration tool for Microsoft RMS connector.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <link><linkText>How to use the server configuration tool for Microsoft RMS connector</linkText><title></title></link> in this topic.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <link><linkText>How to use the server configuration tool for Microsoft RMS connector</linkText><title></title></link> in this topic.

trans-unit.source: For example, to run the tool locally to configure a server running SharePoint 2013:
trans-unit.target: For example, to run the tool locally to configure a server running SharePoint 2013:

trans-unit.source: If you are using SharePoint 2013, make manual registry edits by using the table in the following section to manually add registry settings on the servers.
trans-unit.target: If you are using SharePoint 2013, make manual registry edits by using the table in the following section to manually add registry settings on the servers.

trans-unit.source: Enable IRM in SharePoint.
trans-unit.target: Enable IRM in SharePoint.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <link><linkText>Configure Information Rights Management (SharePoint Server 2010)</linkText><title></title></link> in the SharePoint library.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <link><linkText>Configure Information Rights Management (SharePoint Server 2010)</linkText><title></title></link> in the SharePoint library.

trans-unit.source: When you follow these instructions, you must configure SharePoint to use the connector by specifying Use this RMS server, and then enter the load-balancing connector URL that you configured.
trans-unit.target: When you follow these instructions, you must configure SharePoint to use the connector by specifying Use this RMS server, and then enter the load-balancing connector URL that you configured.

trans-unit.source: Enter the protocol prefix (HTTP:// or HTTPS://) and the name of the connector that you defined in DNS for the load balanced address of your connector.
trans-unit.target: Enter the protocol prefix (HTTP:// or HTTPS://) and the name of the connector that you defined in DNS for the load balanced address of your connector.

trans-unit.source: For example, if your connector name is https://connector.contoso.com, your configuration will look like the following picture:
trans-unit.target: For example, if your connector name is https://connector.contoso.com, your configuration will look like the following picture:

trans-unit.source: After IRM is enabled on a SharePoint farm, you can enable IRM on individual libraries by using the Information Rights Management option on the Library Settings page for each of the libraries.
trans-unit.target: After IRM is enabled on a SharePoint farm, you can enable IRM on individual libraries by using the Information Rights Management option on the Library Settings page for each of the libraries.

trans-unit.source: For SharePoint to access RMS by using the connector, you must authorize the corresponding accounts in the RMS connector administration tool.
trans-unit.target: For SharePoint to access RMS by using the connector, you must authorize the corresponding accounts in the RMS connector administration tool.

trans-unit.source: If you haven’t already done this, see <link><linkText>Authorizing servers to use the RMS connector</linkText><title></title></link> in this topic.
trans-unit.target: If you haven’t already done this, see <link><linkText>Authorizing servers to use the RMS connector</linkText><title></title></link> in this topic.

trans-unit.target: Use the table in the following section only if you want to manually add or check registry settings on a server that runs SharePoint 2013.

trans-unit.target: Windows Server 2012

trans-unit.target: On the file servers configured for File Classification Infrastructure and that will communicate with the RMS connector, do one of the following:

trans-unit.source: Run the server configuration tool for Microsoft RMS connector.

trans-unit.source: Create classification rules and file management tasks to protect documents with RMS Encryption, and then specify an RMS template to automatically apply RMS policies.
trans-unit.target: Create classification rules and file management tasks to protect documents with RMS Encryption, and then specify an RMS template to automatically apply RMS policies.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <link><linkText>File Server Resource Manager Overview</linkText><title></title></link> in the Windows Server documentation library.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <link><linkText>File Server Resource Manager Overview</linkText><title></title></link> in the Windows Server documentation library.

trans-unit.source: Use the table in the following section only if you want to manually add or check registry settings on a file server that uses the File Classification Infrastructure to protect documents.
trans-unit.target: Use the table in the following section only if you want to manually add or check registry settings on a file server that uses the File Classification Infrastructure to protect documents.

trans-unit.source: Instructions for when you use this table:
trans-unit.target: Instructions for when you use this table:

trans-unit.source: ConnectorFQDN is the load-balancing name that you defined in DNS for the connector.
trans-unit.target: ConnectorFQDN is the load-balancing name that you defined in DNS for the connector.

trans-unit.source: For example, rmsconnector.contoso.com.
trans-unit.target: For example, rmsconnector.contoso.com.

trans-unit.source: Use the HTTPS prefix for the connector URL if you have configured the connector to use HTTPS to communicate with your on-premises servers.
trans-unit.target: Use the HTTPS prefix for the connector URL if you have configured the connector to use HTTPS to communicate with your on-premises servers.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see the <link><linkText>Configuring the RMS connector to use HTTPS</linkText><title></title></link> section in this topic.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see the <link><linkText>Configuring the RMS connector to use HTTPS</linkText><title></title></link> section in this topic.

trans-unit.source: The Microsoft RMS URLs always use HTTPS.
trans-unit.target: The Microsoft RMS URLs always use HTTPS.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Next steps
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Next steps

trans-unit.source: Now that the RMS connector is installed and configured, and your servers are configured to use it, IT administrators and users can protect and consume email message and documents by using Azure RMS.
trans-unit.target: Now that the RMS connector is installed and configured, and your servers are configured to use it, IT administrators and users can protect and consume email message and documents by using Azure RMS.

trans-unit.source: To make this easy for users, deploy the RMS sharing application, which installs an add-on for Office and adds new right-click options to File Explorer.
trans-unit.target: To make this easy for users, deploy the RMS sharing application, which installs an add-on for Office and adds new right-click options to File Explorer.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see the <link><linkText>Rights Management sharing application administrator guide</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see the <link><linkText>Rights Management sharing application administrator guide</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: In addition, you might consider the following to help you monitor the RMS connector and your organization’s usage of Azure RMS:
trans-unit.target: In addition, you might consider the following to help you monitor the RMS connector and your organization’s usage of Azure RMS:

trans-unit.source: The built-in Microsoft Rights Management connector performance counters.
trans-unit.target: The built-in Microsoft Rights Management connector performance counters.

trans-unit.source: The <link><linkText>RMS Analyzer tool</linkText><title></title></link>, using the RMS connector option to help you monitor the health of the connector and identify any configuration issues.
trans-unit.target: The <link><linkText>RMS Analyzer tool</linkText><title></title></link>, using the RMS connector option to help you monitor the health of the connector and identify any configuration issues.

trans-unit.target: You can use the <link><linkText>Azure Rights Management Deployment Roadmap</linkText><title></title></link> to check whether there are other configuration steps that you might want to do before you roll out <token href="../Token/aad_rightsmanagement_1_md.md"/> to users and administrators.

trans-unit.source: If there are no other configuration steps that you need to do, see <link><linkText>Using Azure Rights Management</linkText><title></title></link> for operational guidance to support a successful deployment for your organization.
trans-unit.target: If there are no other configuration steps that you need to do, see <link><linkText>Using Azure Rights Management</linkText><title></title></link> for operational guidance to support a successful deployment for your organization.
